         <!-- Start of the content --> 
         <div class="post-content  post-content--narrow"> 
          <h1 class="entry-title  post-content__title  h2"> <a href="http://blog.rapidapi.com/2016/10/07/alexa-api-project/">Amazon Alexa Tutorial: Build Google Translate Skill</a> </h1> 
          <div class="entry-content  post-content__text"> 
           <div class="mailmunch-forms-before-post" style="display: none !important;"></div>
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We just got our hands on the Amazon Echo – a new Alexa-powered voice assistant device from Amazon. Let’s see what we can do with it.</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Amazon Alexa platform is based on </span><b>skills</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Skills are the equivalent of apps for this voice-powered platform. While there are countless skills we could potentially build for Alexa, today we’ll focus on letting users translate words using the Google Translate API. </span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’ll be working from this </span><strong><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill', 'GitHub tutorial');">GitHub tutorial</a></strong><span style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>.</strong> <strong>Directory 01</strong> is for you to edit and work in. If you get stuck, we’ve also created <strong>Directory o2</strong> as a reference with the completed code. </span></p> 
           <h3><b>This article will go through…</b></h3> 
           <ol> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Adding the translation skill to Amazon Alexa</span></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Creating the skill’s backend in AWS Lambda</span></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Connecting Alexa to the Google Translate API using RapidAPI</span></li> 
           </ol> 
           <h3><b>The result</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The end result will look something like this…</span></p> 
           <div style="width: 700px; " class="wp-video">
            <!--[if lt IE 9]><script>document.createElement('video');</script><![endif]--> 
            <video class="wp-video-shortcode" id="video-4-1" width="700" height="394" loop="1" autoplay="1" preload="metadata" controls="controls">
             <source type="video/mp4" src="http://blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Alexa-Tutorial-Ad.mp4?_=1">
             <a href="http://blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Alexa-Tutorial-Ad.mp4">http://blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Alexa-Tutorial-Ad.mp4</a>
            </video>
           </div> 
           <h3><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#what-youll-need" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#what-youll-need', '');" id="user-content-what-youll-need" class="anchor"></a>What you’ll need:</h3> 
           <ul> 
            <li>Amazon Echo device</li> 
            <li>Amazon account</li> 
           </ul> 
           <p>On that note, let the hacking begin!</p> 
           <p><span id="more-4"></span></p> 
           <h2><strong>Step 0: Clone our Repo on GitHub</strong><b><br> </b></h2> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Lucky for you, the first step is the easiest! Clone this</span> <a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill', 'repo on GitHub');"><b>repo on GitHub</b></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> by pasting the following in your terminal:&nbsp;</span></p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="null">git clone https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill.git</pre> 
           <h2><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#step-1-define-the-skills-elements" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#step-1-define-the-skills-elements', '');" id="user-content-step-1-define-the-skills-elements" class="anchor"></a>Step 1: Define the Skill’s Elements</h2> 
           <h3><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1a-create-the-skill" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1a-create-the-skill', '');" id="user-content-1a-create-the-skill" class="anchor"></a><strong>1a: Create the skill</strong></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our new </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Skill</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> will be a voice-powered tool for translating text. This skill means that the user will be able to ask Alexa to translate words or phrases from over 90 languages. For example, the user might say, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Alexa translate “butterfly” to German</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and Alexa will respond by saying, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">The word for “butterfly” in German is Schmetterling</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Pretty cool, right?</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">To get started, we’ll head over to the </span><a href="https://developer.amazon.com/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://developer.amazon.com/', 'Amazon Developer Portal');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Amazon Developer Portal</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and login. If you don’t yet have a developer account, the site will ask you to add some information to your profile (ex. company name), accept a registration agreement, and declare any financial purpose your app may serve (ex. if you plan on monetizing your app). </span></p> 
           <p style="padding-left: 30px;"><i>Pro Tip: the account you use to log in here should be the same account your device is configured with. That way, any skills that you build will sync to your Echo automatically.</i></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Once logged in, head over to the Alexa tab and click “Get Started” under the Alexa Skills Kit block. &nbsp;Next, you’ll click the “Add a New Skill” button near the header of the page. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">The first step in creating a new skill is filling out some basic information in the Skill Information tab. Set your skill’s language to English. The skill’s name is what shows up in the developer dashboard, and the invocation name is what you will actually say out loud when you ask Alexa to call the skill. For ease of use, set your skill name and invocation name “Translate.”</span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Here’s what those first steps look like. </span></p> 
           <p><a href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/4d7871f1d4290f804fde5e827780d1b8c9fa7a52/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f6c304d594d35733843466e78794342474d2e676966" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://camo.githubusercontent.com/4d7871f1d4290f804fde5e827780d1b8c9fa7a52/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f6c304d594d35733843466e78794342474d2e676966', '');" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/4d7871f1d4290f804fde5e827780d1b8c9fa7a52/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f6c304d594d35733843466e78794342474d2e676966" alt="" data-canonical-src="http://i.giphy.com/l0MYM5s8CFnxyCBGM.gif"></a></p> 
           <h3><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1b-define-the-intent" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1b-define-the-intent', '');" id="user-content-1b-define-the-intent" class="anchor"></a><strong>1b. Define the intent</strong></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The next step will be to define the skill’s </span><b>intent</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> schema on the Interaction Model tab. Every skill in the Alexa platform is made of intents. An intent is basically an action that the user can perform with the skill. Our skill will have one intent – Translate. Thus, our definition will look like this:</span></p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="js">{
    "intents": [
        {
            "intent" : "Translate",
            "slots": [
                {
                    "name" : "Source",
                    "type" : "SOURCE"
                },
                {
                    "name" : "Language",
                    "type" : "LANGUAGES_LIST"
                }
            ]
        },
      	{ 
          "intent": "LaunchRequest" 
        }
    ]
}</pre> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Copy and paste this code snippet into the intent schema area. </span></p> 
           <h3><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1c-define-the-slots-and-slot-types" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1c-define-the-slots-and-slot-types', '');" id="user-content-1c-define-the-slots-and-slot-types" class="anchor"></a><strong>1c. Define the slots and slot types</strong></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As you can see in the intent schema code, the intent has two </span><b>slots</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. A slot is like a placeholder for a piece of data that the user can supply to the intent. The slots in our case will be:</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span></p> 
           <ul> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Source: the original word to be translated.</span></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Language: the language we want to translate it to.</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span></li> 
           </ul> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Each of the slots has slot name (“Source” and “Language”) and a </span><b>slot type</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> (SOURCE and LANGUAGES_LIST). A slot type defines what information can go into the slot. You define slot types by providing examples of words that can go in the slot.<br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">For us, the slot types will look like this:</span></p> 
           <p><a href="https://i1.wp.com/github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill/blob/master/screenshots/custom_slots.png?ssl=1" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill/blob/master/screenshots/custom_slots.png', '\n');" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" src="https://i0.wp.com/github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill/raw/master/screenshots/custom_slots.png?w=700&amp;ssl=1" alt="" data-recalc-dims="1"><br> </a></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As you can see, the slot type values for SOURCE are sample words that you may ask Alexa to translate (ex. airplane, butterfly, book etc.). The values for LANGUAGES_LIST are the actual languages you’d like the phrase translated into (ex. German, Dutch, Spanish). </span></p> 
           <h3><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1d-define-the-utterances" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#1d-define-the-utterances', '');" id="user-content-1d-define-the-utterances" class="anchor"></a><strong>1d. Define the utterances</strong></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The last part of the definition is the </span><b>utterances</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. An utterance is an example phrase that the user can say to invoke this specific intent. In other words, utterances are the data Alexa uses to recognize commands. Our utterances will be pretty basic:</span></p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="null">Translate translates {Source} to {Language} 
Translate ask Translate how to say {Source} in {Language} 
Translate ask Translate to translate {Source} to {Language} 
Translate get translation for {Source} in {Language} 
Translate what is {Source} in {Language}</pre> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’ll copy/paste these utterances into “Sample Utterances,” the last section of the interaction model tab.</span></p> 
           <p><img data-attachment-id="656" data-permalink="http://blog.rapidapi.com/2016/10/07/alexa-api-project/screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-10-48-50-am/" data-orig-file="https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?fit=1636%2C548" data-orig-size="1636,548" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-10-48-50-am" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?fit=300%2C100" data-large-file="https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?fit=700%2C234" class="size-medium wp-image-656 aligncenter" src="https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?resize=300%2C100" alt="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-10-48-50-am" srcset="https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?resize=300%2C100 300w, https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?resize=768%2C257 768w, https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?resize=1024%2C343 1024w, https://i1.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-10.48.50-AM.png?w=1400 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-recalc-dims="1"></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Notice that our slots are represented in curly braces {}. These braces allow Alexa to separate variables from static text when the user says a command. The more utterances you define, the better Alexa will be at querying your data. Now that we have the intent, its slots types, and its utterances set, we can move on to configuring our Amazon skill. This step will connect our new skill to a ‘backend’ that will actually perform the translation.</span></p> 
           <h2><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#step-2-connect-to-amazon-lambda" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill#step-2-connect-to-amazon-lambda', '');" id="user-content-step-2-connect-to-amazon-lambda" class="anchor"></a>Step 2: Connect to Amazon Lambda</h2> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In the Configuration tab, define your Service Endpoint to use AWS Lambda. AWS Lambda is a service that lets you write code that runs whenever an event (ex. an HTTP request or an AWS Alexa command) occurs. We will use Lambda in this tutorial so that we will not have to worry about setting up servers, load balancer etc.</span></p> 
           <h3><b>2a. Create or login to AWS account</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Head over to </span><a href="http://aws.amazon.com/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'http://aws.amazon.com/', 'AWS');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">AWS</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> in a new tab and sign in to your console. The login should be the same as your Amazon login from creating a skill. You may have to re-enter some data if you do not already have an AWS account. It will ask you for credit card information, but don’t worry. You won’t be charged unless you go over one million free requests a month. Read more </span><a href="https://aws.amazon.com/pricing/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://aws.amazon.com/pricing/', 'information on AWS pricing');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">information on AWS pricing</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> if you have questions.<br> </span></p> 
           <h3><b>2b. Add an Alexa Skills Kit trigger</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In the console, type “Lambda” in the search bar to be directed to the Lambda service. Next, create a new blank Lambda function and click “Blank Function.” Add the trigger “Alexa Skills Kit” and click next. Here’s what that process looks like:</span></p> 
           <p><img data-attachment-id="657" data-permalink="http://blog.rapidapi.com/2016/10/07/alexa-api-project/aws-lambda-gif/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/AWS-Lambda-gif.gif?fit=480%2C244" data-orig-size="480,244" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="aws-lambda-gif" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/AWS-Lambda-gif.gif?fit=300%2C153" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/AWS-Lambda-gif.gif?fit=480%2C244" class="wp-image-657 aligncenter" src="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/AWS-Lambda-gif.gif?resize=378%2C193" alt="aws-lambda-gif" data-recalc-dims="1"></p> 
           <p>You should now be on the “Configure function” tab. Give your new Lambda function the name “ALEXA-TRANSLATE-SKILL”–the description is optional. &nbsp;Since our code is in Node.js, keep the runtime at Node.js 4.3. &nbsp;Next, set the &nbsp;“Code entry type” to “Upload a .ZIP file,” as seen below.</p> 
           <p><a href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/bc44c10b5e871c4d6187ce2269dbbb078c4fcf80/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f336f365a735455794a6543384232565650612e676966" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://camo.githubusercontent.com/bc44c10b5e871c4d6187ce2269dbbb078c4fcf80/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f336f365a735455794a6543384232565650612e676966', '');" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/bc44c10b5e871c4d6187ce2269dbbb078c4fcf80/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f336f365a735455794a6543384232565650612e676966" alt="" data-canonical-src="http://i.giphy.com/3o6ZsTUyJeC8B2VVPa.gif"></a>.</p> 
           <h3><b>2c. Install the Directory 01 to NPM</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Before uploading the zip file, you’ll need to install all of the dependencies for this particular directory by doing the following:</span></p> 
           <ul> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Go to the Terminal and navigate to the directory 01</span></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Run “npm install”</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span></li> 
           </ul> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This step will allow Alexa to recognize the </span><a href="https://github.com/alexa/alexa-skills-kit-sdk-for-nodejs" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/alexa/alexa-skills-kit-sdk-for-nodejs', 'alexa-sdk');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">alexa-sdk</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> dependency. </span></p> 
           <h3><b>2d. Zip and upload the Directory 01 file to AWS</b><b><br> </b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The code that we zip and upload here will be the code that runs every time that we call an intent on Echo. We will upload a compressed file from directory 01 in our </span><a href="https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://github.com/RapidSoftwareSolutions/Alexa_Google_Translate_Skill', 'GitHub repo.');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">GitHub repo.</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> &nbsp;All this directory 01 code will do is reply to the request by saying something like </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Translating **</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">butterfly** to </span><b>German</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">*. The reply will let us see that all the data is passed correctly. </span><b>Note: directory 01 will not actually </b><b><i>translate </i></b><b>the response yet. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">&nbsp;</span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you haven’t cloned this repository, go ahead and clone it now. </span></p> 
           <ul> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Head over to the directory 01, compress its files and upload the directory to the Lambda page. </span></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure to </span><b>compress the files and the node_modules folder</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and not the directory 01 folder overall, otherwise the skill will not work.</span></li> 
           </ul> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Upload this zip file to the function package button. You don’t have to enable encryption helpers nor add any environment variables for this project.</span></p> 
           <h3><b>2e. Fill in the Lambda Function and Role section</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">After uploading the directory 01 zip file, move on to the Lambda function and role section. For the role, just choose the “Create a custom role” option and when sent to another page, choose “lambda_basic_execution” as the IAM Role. You won’t need to create a new Role policy. </span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">After you fill in your information, the Lambda function code section should look like this. </span></p>
           <div class="mailmunch-forms-in-post-middle" style="display: none !important;"></div> 
           <p><img data-attachment-id="655" data-permalink="http://blog.rapidapi.com/2016/10/07/alexa-api-project/screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-11-39-30-am/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?fit=1022%2C652" data-orig-size="1022,652" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-11-39-30-am" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?fit=300%2C191" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?fit=700%2C447" class="size-medium wp-image-655 aligncenter" src="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?resize=300%2C191" alt="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-11-39-30-am" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?resize=300%2C191 300w, https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?resize=768%2C490 768w, https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?w=1022 1022w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-recalc-dims="1"></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Since this project doesn’t require any advanced settings, go ahead and click “Next,” then click “Create function.”</span></p> 
           <h3><b>2f. Connect Lambda to your Alexa skill</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">To connect the Alexa skill to the Lambda function, simply copy the ARN function identifier of the Lambda function and paste it in the Configuration tab on the Amazon skill settings page (as shown below).</span></p> 
           <p><a href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/30b7f7cd1d87240527f8422be02767cbe84f064b/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f6c3376526841336e4b5030614a4a3753452e676966" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://camo.githubusercontent.com/30b7f7cd1d87240527f8422be02767cbe84f064b/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f6c3376526841336e4b5030614a4a3753452e676966', '');" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/30b7f7cd1d87240527f8422be02767cbe84f064b/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f6c3376526841336e4b5030614a4a3753452e676966" alt="" data-canonical-src="http://i.giphy.com/l3vRhA3nKP0aJJ7SE.gif"></a></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We have now gone through all the steps necessary to create a basic Alexa skill! Woohoo! </span></p> 
           <h3><b>2g. Test your skill </b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In the Alexa developer portal, you can say/type inputs and see this output:</span></p> 
           <p><a href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/e81e5ed6f78ed9bc6231704dd9f60889a943f66e/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f336f37544b4a707664314f46525479736d592e676966" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://camo.githubusercontent.com/e81e5ed6f78ed9bc6231704dd9f60889a943f66e/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f336f37544b4a707664314f46525479736d592e676966', '');" target="_blank"><img src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/e81e5ed6f78ed9bc6231704dd9f60889a943f66e/687474703a2f2f692e67697068792e636f6d2f336f37544b4a707664314f46525479736d592e676966" alt="" data-canonical-src="http://i.giphy.com/3o7TKJpvd1OFRTysmY.gif"></a></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have an Amazon Alexa compatible device like the Amazon Echo, you can try the skill on it. If you used the same account while configuring and creating the skill, the Translate skill will show up automatically under </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your skills</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> on the Alexa app.<br> </span><br> <span style="font-weight: 400;">If all goes well, you should get a result where the Alexa skill repeats exactly what you are saying (ex. “Translate butterfly to German”) versus an actual translation. </span></p> 
           <h2><b>Step 3: Add the Translation Functionality with RapidAPI</b></h2> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">While this is all very exciting (we have an Alexa skill now!), our skill doesn’t actually translate anything. Yet!<br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">The next (and last step) will be to add the actual translation functionality. We’ll use </span><a href="https://goo.gl/tgnLDY" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/tgnLDY', 'RapidAPI');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">RapidAPI</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to connect to the </span><a href="https://goo.gl/Ri3JxT" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/Ri3JxT', 'Google Translate API');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Google Translate API</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Here’s how it works: </span></p> 
           <h3><b>3a. Connect to the Google Translate API with RapidAPI</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’re using RapidAPI for two reasons: it lets you test and call APIs in the browser and you can export the code snippet that calls the API directly into the project. </span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Head over to </span><a href="https://goo.gl/Ri3JxT" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/Ri3JxT', 'RapidAPI’s Google Translate');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">RapidAPI’s Google Translate</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> package. You’ll notice that this API requires an API key. To get the Google Translate API key, do the following: </span></p> 
           <ol> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href="https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/projects" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/projects', 'Go to the projects page');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Go to the projects page</span></a></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Select or create a Cloud Platform Console project. </span></li> 
           </ol> 
           <p style="padding-left: 30px;"><img data-attachment-id="658" data-permalink="http://blog.rapidapi.com/2016/10/07/alexa-api-project/screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-4-33-00-pm/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-4.33.00-PM.png?fit=559%2C256" data-orig-size="559,256" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-4-33-00-pm" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-4.33.00-PM.png?fit=300%2C137" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-4.33.00-PM.png?fit=559%2C256" class="size-medium wp-image-658 aligncenter" src="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-4.33.00-PM.png?resize=300%2C137" alt="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-4-33-00-pm" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-4.33.00-PM.png?resize=300%2C137 300w, https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-4.33.00-PM.png?w=559 559w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-recalc-dims="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">3.&nbsp;<a href="https://support.google.com/cloud/answer/6293499#enable-billing" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://support.google.com/cloud/answer/6293499#enable-billing', 'Enable billing');">Enable billing</a></span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for your project. Don’t worry–you’ll get a thirty day free trial and Google will not automatically charge you after the trial ends.<br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">4. Click “Use Google APIs” and search for the Google Translate API.<br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">5. Click the “Enable” button on the Google Translate API page.<br> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">6. Navigate to the credentials tab on the left of the screen to get an API key (select API key when prompted). </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Note: If you have an existing API key, you can use that key.</span></i></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Now, you can test the call with RapidAPI. Go back to the </span><a href="https://goo.gl/Ri3JxT" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/Ri3JxT', 'Google Translate package page');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Google Translate package page</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, fill in your API key and parameters for an API call to test it out for yourself. </span></p> 
           <p><img class="size-medium aligncenter" src="https://i2.wp.com/media4.giphy.com/media/pKhw5rbUpsEuI/giphy.gif?resize=480%2C226" alt="" data-recalc-dims="1"></p> 
           <p>Nifty, am I right? Feel free to test out multiple calls/languages.</p> 
           <h3><b>3b. Install RapidAPI into Directory 01</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In order to export the code snippet for the API call, you’ll need to get a <a href="https://goo.gl/tgnLDY" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/tgnLDY', 'RapidAPI');">RapidAPI</a> account. You can sign in with GitHub, Facebook, Google or a custom email/password. </span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Once you sign up for RapidAPI, you will be prompted to create a new project. Go ahead and name it RapidAPI Translate. The next window will prompt you to pick a language. Leave the language setting at Node.js and copy the two lines under “Require SDK.” They should look something like this: </span></p> 
           <p>&nbsp;</p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="js">const RapidAPI = new require('rapidapi-connect');
const rapid = new RapidAPI('PROJECT-NAME', 'RAPIDAPI APP ID');</pre> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Open the index.js file. This is the code run by the Lambda function to handle requests sent to the skill. At the top of the file, add the copied lines to connect to RapidAPI.</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Once you have the RapidAPI credentials in index.js file, navigate to the 01 directory and install the RapidAPI SDK by running the following line in the command line.</span></p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="null">npm install rapidapi-connect --save</pre> 
           <h3><b>3c. Incorporate Google Translate snippet</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’re on the home stretch! Now, we’ll copy and paste the following code snippets into index.js.<br> </span><br> <span style="font-weight: 400;">First, put this language code object at the top of the Translate function. Your code should look like this: </span><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br> </span></p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="js">'Translate': function() {
    const langCodes = {
        "German" : "de",
        "Dutch" : "nl",
        "English" : "en",
        "French" : "fr",
        "Italian" : "it",
        "Polish" : "pl",
        "Russian" : "ru",
        "Spanish" : "es"
    };
</pre> 
           <p>&nbsp;</p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Next, you’ll need to add a variable that can access the language codes from the above object. Add this line directly beneath the object: </span></p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="js">var langCode = langCodes[language];</pre> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Next, grab the RapidAPI call and put it at the very bottom of the function. </span></p> 
           <pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="null">rapid.call('GoogleTranslate', 'translateAutomatic', {
       'apiKey': 'Your Google API key',
        'string': word,
        'targetLanguage': langCode

    }).on('success', (payload) =&gt; {
      this.emit(":tell", `${word} is ${payload} in ${language}`);
    }).on('error', (payload) =&gt; {
      this.emit(":tell", "Sorry, translation was unsuccessful..");
    });</pre> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">So, what did we just do? Every time the Lambda function gets a request, it call the exports.handler function (last function in the code). If the type of the request is LaunchRequest (meaning the user is trying to get the skill to perform an intent, “ask Translate”), the request will call the “LaunchRequest” function. If the name of the intent is Translate (we defined this as the only valid intent in our skill), the request will call the “Translate” function. That’s the function we’ll use to perform the translation.<br> </span></p> 
           <h3><b>3d. Compare your code to Directory 02</b></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you followed the directions above, you should</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> have a fully working translation function! If you’re running into trouble, compare your directory to the reference directory 02. </span></p> 
           <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;"><b>3e. Compress the files and upload them to the Amazon Lambda function<br> </b></span></h3> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">This is the final step! Moment of truth. Compress all the files in the directory 01 (remember to compress the individual files vs. the directory 01 folder). Next, go back to </span><a href="https://console.aws.amazon.com/lambda/home?region=us-east-1#/create/configure-function?firstrun=true" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://console.aws.amazon.com/lambda/home?region=us-east-1#/create/configure-function?firstrun=true', 'Amazon Lambda');"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Amazon Lambda</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and upload your compressed file under “Lambda Function Code.”</span></p> 
           <p><img data-attachment-id="655" data-permalink="http://blog.rapidapi.com/2016/10/07/alexa-api-project/screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-11-39-30-am/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?fit=1022%2C652" data-orig-size="1022,652" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-11-39-30-am" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?fit=300%2C191" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?fit=700%2C447" class="size-medium wp-image-655 aligncenter" src="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?resize=300%2C191" alt="screen-shot-2017-01-25-at-11-39-30-am" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?resize=300%2C191 300w, https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?resize=768%2C490 768w, https://i0.wp.com/blog.rapidapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Screen-Shot-2017-01-25-at-11.39.30-AM.png?w=1022 1022w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" data-recalc-dims="1"></p> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">When you test the function this time, it should have full translation capabilities. No more repeating what you’ve said, Alexa should now be able to translate your phrases.<br> </span></p> 
           <h2>Success!</h2> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Congratulations–you’ve just built an Alexa skill! While this project used the Google Translate API, you can also build more skills with different APIs and a similar process. Here are some other Amazon Alexa skill ideas to keep you coding: </span></p> 
           <ul> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ask Alexa to check flight status with the <a href="https://goo.gl/gkgxP4" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/gkgxP4', 'Laminar Flight Data API');">Laminar Flight Data API</a>&nbsp;</span></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Prompt Alexa to send text messages with <a href="https://goo.gl/zjlMnm" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/zjlMnm', 'Twilio’s API');">Twilio’s API</a> (here’s a <a href="https://goo.gl/WdJO8z" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/WdJO8z', 'Twilio tutorial) ');">Twilio tutorial) </a></span></li> 
            <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have Alexa check you in with the <a href="https://goo.gl/edLZWN" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'https://goo.gl/edLZWN', 'Foursquare&nbsp;API');">Foursquare&nbsp;API</a></span></li> 
           </ul> 
           <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Comment with links to any of your projects and happy hacking! </span></p>
